_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



PENDLETON GRAIN GROWERS - McKENNON STATION



We are a fertilizer retail facility.  The only materials considered hazardous at our facility are anhydrous ammonia and aqua (a 20wt% solution of ammonia in water).  The only flammable substance at our site is propane.  Our facility has one 30,000 gallon tank for storing anhydrous, an atmospheric-pressure 15,000 gallon tank for storing aqua, and an atmospheric-pressure 7,000 gallon tank for storing aqua.  The propane tank holds 18,000-gallons.  We have equipment for receiving anhydrous by truck and by rail, equipment for receiving aqua by truck, and equipment for transferring anhydrous and aqua from storage to trucks for delivery to customers.  We have equipment for receiving propane from truck transports and transferring propane from storage to trucks for delivery to customers.  It is our policy to meet, or exceed, all local, state, and national standards relating to handling ammonia.



Site-Specific Process Safety Information is tabulated below.  Specific safety features that we employ to minimize the impact of an accidental release include:



1.  Pull-away shut-off valves that immediately shut to minimize the amount of anhydrous released if a truck accidentally leaves before disconnecting hoses.

2.  Emergency shut-off valves to minimize the amount anhydrous released if anything unusual occurs during loading or unloading.

3.  Excess flow valves to prevent flow from the tank if any propane or anhydrous hose or line breaks.

4.  Pressure relief valves on the anhydrous storage tank to prevent overpressuring and rupture of the tank.

5.  Diking around the aqua storage tank, to contain any accidental spills.

6.  Emergency shut-off valves, with both local and remote activation, to minimize the amount released if anything unusual occurs during loading or unloading propane.

7. Annual inspections by independent inspectors to ensure that our equipment is maintained in the manner that ensures safe oper

ation and prevents releases.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

A Hazard Analysis was performed and results are shown below.



HAZARD ANALYSIS FOR ANHYDROUS STORAGE



GENERAL            

What if?:            Fire occurs at or around storage facility?    

Consequence:        Potential to overheat and overpressure storage tanks, potential tank damage and/or release of ammonia.    Safeguards:        Grass, brush, flammables kept a minimum of 10 feet from anhydrous storage tanks.  Relief valves on storage tank protect against overpressure.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Flood occurs at storage facility?    

Consequence:        Potential to lift and damage tanks and/or lines, potential release of ammonia.    Facility not in flood plain.  

Safeguards:        Excess flow valves on storage tanks minimize release of ammonia.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate .



What if?:            Storage facility is hit by tornado?    

Consequence:        Potential to lift and damage tank and/or lines, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Excess flow valves on storage tanks minimize release of ammonia.    

Recommendatio

n:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Facility is hit by lightning?    

Consequence:        Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia. 

Safeguards:        Excess flow valves on storage tanks minimize release of ammonia. Tank is grounded.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            There is a power outage?    

Consequence:        Potentially unable to load or unload.  No safety consequences.

        

What if?:            Vehicle impacts facility?    

Consequence:        Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Tank located far from roadway. Load out area is barricaded.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



TRANSPORT            

What if?:            Transport contains something other than ammonia?    

Consequence:        Potential to contaminate ammonia storage, potential to overheat and damage tank from heat of reaction.

Safeguards:        Agreement with supplier to only supply ammonia.  Relief valves on storage tank protect against overpressure.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Transport/railcar rolls during loading/unloading?    

Consequence:        Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Wheels chocked and brake set prior to connecting hoses.  Excess flow valves on transport.

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Transport/railcar leaves before disconnecting hoses?    

Consequence:        Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.    Safeguards:        Excess flow valves.     

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Transport level gauge malfunctions?    

Consequence:        Potential to overfill storage tank, potential to overpressure and damage storage tank, potential to release ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Driver present during the filling procedure, level gauge on the storage tank, relief valves tank prevents overexposure and damage.     

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Liquid transfer hose valve leaks?    

Consequence:

Potential to deliver more ammonia than truck should hold.  Potential for storage tank to be overfull when temperature rises, potential to overpressure and damage storage tank, potential to release ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Relief valves on ammonia storage tank protect against overpressure.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



HOSES/CONNECTIONS            

What if?:            Liquid transfer hose valve leaks?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Operator trained to check valves, operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Gas masks and water trough.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Vapor transfer hose valve leaks?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Operator trained to check valves, operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Gas masks and water trough.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Liquid hose disconnected before transport liquid valve shut?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick valve closing.  Excess flow valve on transport. Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles. Ammonia odor.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Vapor hose disconnected before transport liquid valve shut?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick valve closing.  Excess flow valve on transport. Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles. Ammonia odor. Gas Masks and water trough.    Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Liquid hose disconnected before facility liquid transfer valve shut?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Hose and tra

nsport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose to facilitate valve closing and minimize release.  Excess flow valve on tank.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles.  Gas mask and water trough.  

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Vapor hose disconnected before facility vapor transfer valve shut?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose to facilitate valve closing and minimize release.  Excess flow valve on tank.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles.  Gas mask and water trough.    Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Vapor hose ruptures?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Excess flow valves.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles.  Gas masks and water trough.    Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Liquid hose ruptures?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.    

Safeguards:        Excess flow valves.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles.  Gas masks and water trough.    Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



PUMP/COMPRESSOR

What if?:            Pump seal leaks?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.    

Safeguards:        Block valves located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Pump suction plugged?    

Consequence:        Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Block valves located on suction on discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.                

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Pump discharge plugged?    

Consequence:        Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Block valves located on suction on discharge of pump to isolat

e leak.  Operator present during pump operation.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



AMMONIA STORAGE TANK        

What if?:            Storage tank overfilled to overflowing?    

Consequence:        Potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.  

Safeguards:        Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity is greater than transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What If?:            Storage tank overfilled, but not overflowed?    

Consequence:        Potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank when ambient temperature rises, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity is greater than transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Liquid line to storage tank blocked in liquid full?    

Consequence:        Potential to overpressure and damage line/hose, potential to release ammonia.

Safeguards:        Hydrostatic relief valves installed in lines with potential to be blocked in liquid full, excess flow valves in lines on storage tank.    Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Storage tank level gauge malfunctions.    

Consequence:        Potential to overfill storage tank, potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential  release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity is greater than transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Storage tank temperature gauge malfunctions?    

Consequence:        Potential to overfill storage tank, potential overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Driver present during filling procedure, ta

S 



NURSE TANK/TRUCK LOADING FROM BULK STORAGE



WARNING:         Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.

                         Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns. 

                      ALWAYS wear filter mask or splash goggles when working on ammonia lines.

                      ALWAYS wear rubber/Neoprene safety gloves when working on ammonia lines.

                      ALWAYS vent line away from you.



CAUTION:         Never leave transfer operation unattended.

                          If necessary to leave area, find a qualified person to attend the operation, or stop the operation.



1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2. Spot the nurse tank/truck in loading area.

3. Ensure nurse tank/truck is chocked.

4. Remove nozzle caps on nurse tank/truck nozzles.



If necessary, clean connector with a rag and replace worn or damaged gaskets or O-rings.



5. Connect liquid and vapor hoses.



CAUTION:      Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.

                        Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.

        Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed way from your body.



6. Ensure that liquid and vapor valves on storage tank are open.

7. Ensure that pump/compressor suction and discharge valves are open.

8. Open vapor and liquid hose valves.

9. Open vapor and liquid valves on nurse tank/truck.

10. Start pump/compressor.



WARNING:          If a leak or fire occurs, stop pump immediately.

                             Leak:  If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.

                            Fire:    If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.



11. When filling level is reached, stop pump/compressor.

12. Close vapor and liquid valves on nurse tank/truck.

13. Close vapor and liquid hose valves.

14. Either:

    A. Crack connection to release pressure, or

    B. Open bleeder valve to release pressure.

15. Disconne

nk nearly empty before filling and tank capacity is greater than transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Storage tank has excess corrosion/erosion?    

Consequence:        Potential storage tank crack, rupture or leak, potential release of ammonia.    

Safeguards:        Storage tank internals remain in oxygen free non-corrosive atmosphere.  Storage tank external is well maintained, painted and routinely visually inspected.

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Relief valve fails to lift when needed?    

Consequence:        Potential to overpressure and damage the storage tank, potential ammonia release.    

Safeguards:        Relief valves inspected annually, and replaced every 5 years.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Relief valve lifts below set pressure?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release through relief valve.    

Safeguards:        Relief valves inspected annually, and replaced every 5 years.    

Recommendation:        Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Relief valve fails to reset?    

Consequence:        Potential ammonia release.    

Safeguards:        Relief valves inspected annually, and replaced every 5 years.    Recommendation?        Safeguards adequate.

HAZARD ANALYSIS FOR PROPANE STORAGE



GENERAL

What if:            Fire occurs at or around storage facility?

Consequence:        Potential to overheat and overpressure storage tank, potential tank damage and/or release of propane, potential for larger fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if:            Flood occurs at storage facility?

Consequence:        Potential to lift and damage tank and/or lines, potential release of propane, potential for fire and/or explosion.

Safeguards:        Excess flow valves on storage tank to minimize release of propane.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if:            Storage facility is hit by tornado?

Consequence:        Potential to lift and damage tank and/or lines, potential release of propane, potential for fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Excess flow valves on storage tank to minimize release of propane.

What if:            Facility is hit by lightening?

Consequence:        Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment, potential release of propane, potential for fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Propane liquid and vapors are contained in closed vessels and piping.  Excess flow valves on storage tank to minimize release of propane.

Consequence:        Potentially unable to load or unload.  N

o safety consequences.

Recommendations:    

Safeguards:

Recommendations:    Barricades around tanks and bulkheads protect tanks and bulkheads from vehicle impact.

What if:            Storage tank overfilled, but not overflowed?

Consequence:        Potential overpressure and/or damage to storage tank when ambient temperature rises, potential release of propane, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Driver present during filling procedures, level gauges on the storage tank and transport, relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.

Safeguards:        Safeguards adequate.



What if:            Liquid line to storage tank blocked in liquid full?

Consequence:        Potential to overpressure and damage line/hose, potential to release propane, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Hydrostatic relief valves installed in lines with potential to be blocked in liquid full, excess flow valves in lines on storage tank.

Safeguards:        Safeguards adequate.



What if:            Storage tank level gauge malfunctions?

Consequence:        Potential to over fill storage tank, potential overpressure and/or damage to storage tank, potential release of propane, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Driver present during filling procedure, propane storage tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity is greater than transport capacity, relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure an

d damage.

Safeguards:        Safeguards adequate.



What if:            Storage tank temperature gauge malfunctions?

Consequence:        Potential overpressure and/or damage storage tank when ambient temperature rises, potential release of propane, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Driver present during filling procedure, level gauges on the storage tank and transport, relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.

Safeguards:        Safeguards adequate.



What if:            Storage tank paint deteriorated/storage tank has excess corrosion/erosion?

Consequence:        Potential for storage tank to crack, rupture or leak, potential release of propane, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Storage tank internals remain in an oxygen free non-corrosive atmosphere.

Safeguards:        Ensure storage tank well painted.



What if:            Relief valve fails to lift when needed?

Consequence:        Potential to overpressure and damage the storage tank, potential propane release, potential for fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    Propane service is non corrosive.

Safeguards:        See STORAGE TANK, storage tank overfilled to overflowing.



What if:            Relief valve lifts below set pressure?

Consequence:        Potential excess loss of propane through relief valve, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    All ignitions sources are kept a minimum of 25 ft. from tanks.

Safeguards:        See STORAGE TANK, Storage tank overfilled to overflowing.



What if:            Relief valve fails to reset?

Consequence:        Potential release of propane, potential fire and/or explosion.

Recommendations:    All ignition sources are kept a minimum of 25 ft. from tanks.

Safeguards:        See STORAGE TANK, Storage tank overfilled to overflowing.

ve.

For Leak:        If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.

4.  Ensure the bobtail is chocked.

7.  Note bobtail capacity.

9.  Ensure hoses and connectors are clean and in good condition.

10.  Connect vapor and liquid transfer hoses to bobtail.



NEVER DRAG A HOSE CONNECTOR OR VALVE ACROSS THE GROUND.

ALWAYS CARRY BY THE VALVE BODY WITH THE OUTFLOW POINTED AWAY FROM YOUR BODY.



11.  Check operation of ESVs.

12.  Open vapo

r valves on bobtail and on transfer hose.

14.  Start compressor/pump, check connections for leaks.



WARNING:    IF A LEAK OR FIRE OCCURS, CLOSE ESVs AND STOP COMPRESSOR/PUMP IMMEDIATELY.



For Leak:        If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.

For Fire:        If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.  PHONE 911.



15.  Monitor filling with level gauge on bobtail.

21.  Record temperature and level of propane in bobtail.



Our Maintenance Policy and Procedures are described below.



MAINTENANCE POLICY



1. Employees performing maintenance are trained to safely maintain storage tanks and equipment, and are certified as required by the Training Policy.

2. Maintenance contractors are required to certify that their employees are qualified to perform job tasks in a safe manner.

3. Equipment is inspected during normal operations and deficiencies are reported to the shop foreman.  The facility is inspected periodically an insurance company loss control specialist.  Inspection reports are on file in the company office.

4. Maintenance procedures follow.



REMOVE/REPLACE PUMP OR COMPRESSOR

Remove Pump/Compressor:



WARNING:         Before removing/replacing a pump or compressor, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.



1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2. Ensure line segment which includes pump/compressor is protected from any energy source (i.e. pump/compressor block valves are closed and locked).

3. Ensure breaker for pump/compressor is in off position, tagged, and locked to prevent anyone from inadvertently switching breaker on.

4. Disconnect electrical wiring from pump/compre

ssor.

5. If there is a vent valve in the line segment, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is no vent valve in the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the flanges on the suction and discharge side of the pump/compressor flange as described in Step 6.)

6. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting. 



CAUTION:        If the line does not stop venting, make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If other lines are not venting to the line segment, a block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank may need to be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.



NOTE:         Procedure, REMOVING AMMONIA FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



7. Continue by loosening all flange bolts.

8. Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

9. Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.

10. Remove coupling or drive belt.

11. Loosen base mount bolts.

12. Remove pump/compressor.  If necessary use hoist or crane to prevent injury when removing pump/compressor.



Replace Pump/Compressor

1.    Inspect pump/compressor flanges for scratches or defects.    



NOTE:         Do not reinstall pump/compressor with badly scratched or galled flanges.



2. Clean flanges if necessary.

3. Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.

4. Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5. Place pump/compressor back on base mounts.  Use rigged hoist/crane if necessary.  Tighten base mount bolts in start pattern two or three time to ensure a solid foundation.

6. Insert

flange bolts and new gaskets.

9. Align and replace coupling or drive belt.

10. Reconnect electrical wiring to pump/compressor.

11. Return pump/compressor breaker to the 'ON' position and test the pump/compressor to ensure the wiring was reconnected correctly.

12. Open block valves and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.

13. Clean and store tools.

d by aqua service by checking container label.

NOTE:               Procedure:  REMOVI

NG AMMONIA FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



4. Remove existing tank gauge/valve, nozzle cover or cap.

CAUTION:        If pipe tap binds, stop chasing.  Do not force the tap.

REMOVING AMMONIA FROM A STORAGE TANK



This procedure is to permit maintenance that requires reducing the tank pressure to 0 psig.  The procedure involves:



1. Removing liquid ammonia from the storage tank to an ammonia transport/nurse tank, then

2. Removing residual ammonia vapor from the storage tank by absorbing the vapor in water in a transport or in another storage tank.



WARNING:         Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.

                            Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.

        Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

                            Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

                            Always vent line away from you.



CAUTI

ON:         Never leave transfer operation unattended.

                           If necessary to leave area, find a qualified person to attend the operation, or stop the operation.



Remove Liquid Ammonia:

1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2. Ensure that transport/nurse tanks are approved for ammonia, and transport/nurse tanks are available with enough capacity to hold liquid remaining in storage tank.



ANYHYDROUS AMMONIA should be clearly marked on the transport/nurse tank.



3. Spot the transport/nurse tank.

4. Ensure transport/nurse tank is chocked.

5. Connect vapor and liquid hoses.



If necessary, clean connectors with a rag and replace worn or damaged gaskets or O-rings.



CAUTION:         Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.

                           Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.

        Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed away from your body.



6. Ensure that liquid and vapor valves at storage tank are open.

7. Ensure that pump suction and discharge valves are open.

8. Open liquid and vapor valves.

9. Open liquid and vapor valves on transport/nurse tank.

10. Start pump.



WARNING:        If a leak of fire occurs, stop pump and close valves immediately.

                           Leak:  If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.

                           Fire:    If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible, CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.



11. Remove liquid ammonia until either:

    A) All liquid is removed (pump will start to activate), or

    B) Transport/nurse tank is 85% full.

12.  Stop pump.

13. Close liquid and vapor valves on transport/nurse tank.

14. Close liquid and vapor hose valves.

15. Close liquid and vapor valves at storage tank.

16. Crack liquid and vapor hose connections to allow pressure to bleed off.

17. After pressure has bled from lines, disconnect vapor and liquid hoses.



WARNING:     After liquid is remo

ved, vapor remaining in the tank may cause dangerously high pressure to remain in the tank.



Use following procedure to remove vapor remaining in tank.



Remove Residual Ammonia Vapor:



WARNING:      Always wear splash goggles when working on ammonia lines.

                         Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

                         Always vent lines away from you.



This procedure transfers  pressurized ammonia vapor from the storage tank to water in a transport or storage tank, where the ammonia is absorbed into water.



CAUTION:   Considerable heat is evolved when ammonia dissolves in water.  To avoid overheating and damaging the transport or receiving storage tank, be sure that at least 5000 gal of water is in the transport or receiving storage tank.



1. If vapor is transferred to a vehicle, ensure that vehicle contains water, is chocked, and approved for ammonia.

2. Connect liquid hose to vehicle, trough, or storage tank containing water.

3. Open pump bypass valves.

4. Slowly open liquid hose valve.

5. If transfer is to a vehicle, open liquid valve on vehicle.

6. Monitor vapor transfer by observing pressure on the ammonia storage tank pressure gauge.



CAUTION:        If strong ammonia odor occurs before pressure decreases to 0 psig, solution has probably become saturated with ammonia.  In this case close valves on liquid line, dispose of the solution, refill water, and repeat steps 2 through 6.



7. When pressure gauge indicates 0 psig, close all valves.

8. Open vent or vapor valve on storage tank to relieve any remaining pressure.

9. Disconnect and store hose.

10. Dispose of ammonia solution according to company policy.



MAINTENANCE POLICY FOR PROPANE



REMOVE/REPLACE PUMP OR COMPRESSOR



Remove Pump/Compressor:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing a pump or compressor, ensure that line segment is vented down to atmospheric pressure.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (min

imum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Ensure line segment, which includes pump-compressor, is protected from any energy source (i.e., block valve is closed and locked between pump-compressor and storage tank).

4.  Ensure breaker for pump-compressor is in off positions and tagged to prevent anyone from inadvertently switching breaker on.

5.  Disconnect electrical wiring from pump/compressor.



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor releases can cause frostbite.

        Wear vinyl safety gloves during entire operation and always vent line away from you.



6.  If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.  

(If there is NO valve to vent the line segment, the lines segment may be vented from the flanges on the suction and discharge side of the pump-compressor as described in Step 7).



7.  Loosen the flange bolts on the opposite side of flange (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, only far enough to start the line segment venting.



CAUTION:    If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other line are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be depressured to remove-replace the pump/compressor.



NOTE:        REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressuring tanks.



8.  Continue by loosening all flange bolts.

9.  Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

10.  Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.

11.  Remove coupling.

12.  Loosen base mount bolts.

13.  Remove pump/compressor.  If necessary use hoist or crane to prevent injury when removing pump/compressor.



Replace Pump/Compressor:



1.  Inspect pump/compressor flanges for scratches or defects.



NOTE:    Do not reinstall pump/compressor with badly scratched or galled flanges.



2.  Clean flanges if necessary.

3.  Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.

4.  Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5.  Place

pump/compressor back on base mounts.  Use a rigged hoist/crane if necessary.  Tighten base mount bolts in star pattern two or three times to ensure a solid foundation.

6.  Insert bolts and new gaskets.

7.  Tighten bolts in a cross pattern.

8.  Repeat tightening to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)

9.  Align and replace coupling.

10.  Reconnect electrical wiring to pump/compressor.

11.  Return pump/compressor breaker to the 'ON' position and test the pump/compressor to ensure the wiring was reconnected correctly.

12.  Open block valve and allow line to pump/compressor to pressure with propane and check for leaks.

13.  Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE FLANGED VALVE



Remove Valve:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing valve, ensure that line segment is vented down to atmospheric pressure.



NOTE:        INSTALLING VALVES covers installing valves directly on tanks.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Ensure line segment, which includes valve, is protected from any energy source (i.e. block valve is closed and locked between valve and storage tank).



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor can cause frostbite.

        Wear vinyl safety gloves during entire operations and always vent line away from you.



4.  If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.

5.  If there is NO valve to vent the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the valve.

6.  Loosen the flange bolts on the opposite side of flange (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away form you).  Gently pry the flange apart, only far enough to start the line segment venting.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other line are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines, the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage ta

nk must be depressured to remove/replace the valve.



NOTE:        REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



7.  Begin removing valve by loosening bolts on opposite side of flanges (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).



CAUTION:    If line note adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



8.  Continue by loosening all flange bolts.  If necessary, rig hoist/jack to support valve.

9.  Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

10.  Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.

11.  Remove valve.



Replace Valve:



1.  Inspect valve flanges for scratches or defects.



NOTE:        Do not install valve with badly scratched or galled flanges.



2.  Clean flanges if necessary.

3.  Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.

4.  Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5.  Place valve in position and make sure valve is oriented so that pipeline flow is in the same direction as the arrow on the valve.  Use a rigged hoist/jack if necessary.

6.  Insert bolts and new gaskets.

7.  Tighten bolts in a cross pattern.

8.  Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)

9.  Open block valve and allow line to pressure with propane and check for leaks.

10.  Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE THREADED VALVE



Remove Valve:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing valve, ensure that lien segment is vented down to atmospheric pressure.



NOTE:        INSTALLING VALVES covers installing valves directly on tanks.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Ensure line segment, which includes valve, is protected from any energy source (i.e. block valve is closed and locked between valve and storage tank).



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor can cause frostbite.

        Wear vinyl safety gloves during entire operations and

always vent line away from you.



4.  If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.

5.  If there is NO valve to vent the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the valve.

6.  Loosen the valve packing only until propane begins to vent from the line segment.  When the venting has stopped, carefully loosen the packing to ensure the line segment has fully vented.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other line are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be depressured to remove/replace the valve.



NOTE:        REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



7.  Begin removing valve by slowly loosening union or valve thread.



CAUTION:  If line note adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



8.  Continue by loosening until valve is free.  If necessary, rig hoist/jack to support valve.

9.  Remove Valve. 



Replace Valve:



1.  Clean valve threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts.



2.  Clean line threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.

3.  Apply thread sealing compound to male threads.



Ensure that compound is approved for propane service by checking container label.



4.  Carefully screw threaded valve onto line.



Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.



5.  Open block valve and allow line to pressure with propane and check for leaks.

6.  Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE FLANGE GASKET



Remove Gasket:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing valve, ensure that line segment is vented down to atmospheric pressure.



NOTE:        INSTALLING VALVES covers installing valves directly on tanks.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (mini

mum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Ensure line segment, which includes valve, is protected from any energy source (i.e. block valve is closed and locked between gasket and storage tank).



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor can cause frostbite.

        Wear vinyl safety gloves during entire operations and always vent line away from you.



4.  If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.

5.  If there is NO valve to vent the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the gasketed flange.

6.  Loosen the flange bolts on the opposite side of flange (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, only far enough to start the line segment venting.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be depressured to remove/replace the gasket.



NOTE:        REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



7.  Begin removing gasket by loosening bolts on opposite side of flanges (to direct any spray, from residual content in line, away from you).



CAUTION:    If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



8.  Continue by loosening all flange bolts.

9.  Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

10.  Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gasket.



Replace Gasket:



1.  Inspect gasket and flanges for scratches or defeats.



NOTE:        Do not reinstall gasket with any defects.



2.  Clean flanges if necessary.

3.  Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.

4.  Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5.  Insert two bolts and slide new gasket into position.

6.  Insert remaining bolts and tighten in a cross pattern.

7.  Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)

8.  Open block valve and allow line

to pressure with propane and check for leaks.

9.  Clean and store tools.



INSTALLING FLANGES VALVES ON STORAGE TANKS



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor released can cause eye damage and frostbite.



        Wear splash goggles and vinyl safety gloves during entire operation.

        Always vent line away from you.



WARNING:    Before installing valve, ensure that tank is empty and at 0 psig pressure.



NOTE:        REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Remove any dust caps, plugs, or covers from valve.

4.  Clean valve flange and container flange with cleaning solvent approved for propane.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts.



5.  Ensure that flange surfaces are free of nicks and other damage.

6.  Ensure that bolts are correct size.

7.  Apply anti-seize compound to bolt threads.

8.  Install gasket and valve.



Ensure that gasket is approved for propane service by checking container label.



    A.      Top-mounted valve:

        I.    Place gasket on container flange

        II.    Place valve on top of gasket

        III.    Insert bolts.

        IV.    Tighten bolts in opposing pattern.

    B.    Side- and bottom-mounted valve:

        I.    Support valve in position.

        II.    Insert bolts on three sides (Bottom and side for side-mounted valves.)

        III.    Insert gasket.

        IV.    Insert remaining bolts

        V.    Tighten bolts in opposing pattern.



9.  For pressure relief valves:  Install discharge pipe and rain cover.  (Must be at least 7 ft. high.)

10.  Clean and store tools.



INSTALLING THREADED VALVES ON STORAGE TANKS



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor release can cause eye damage and frostbite.



        Wear splash goggles and vinyl safety gloves during entire operation.

        Always vent line away from you.



WARNING:    Before installing valve, ensure that tank is empty and at 0 psig pressure.



NOTE:        REMOVING

PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Remove any dust caps, plugs, or covers from valve.

4.  Clean valve mounting threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts.



5.  Remove any propane tank nozzle cover or cap.

6.  Chase container female threads with proper size pipe tap.



CAUTION:    If pipe tap binds, stop chasing.  Do not force the tap.



7.  Clean container threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.

8.  Apply thread sealing compound to male threads.



Ensure that compound is approved for propane service by checking container label.



9.  Carefully screw threaded valve into opening.



Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  No not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.



10.  For Pressure Relief Valves:  Install discharge pipe with rain cover.  (Must be at least 7 ft. high.)

11.  Clean and store tools.



INSTALLING GAUGES ON STORAGE TANKS



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor release can cause eye damage and frostbite.



        Wear splash goggles and vinyl safety gloves during entire operation.

        Always vent line away from you.



WARNING:    Before installing gauge, ensure that tank is empty and at 0 psig pressure, unless gauge is mounted in well that protect the gauge from contents in the tank.



NOTE:        REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignitions sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Remove any dust carps, plugs, or covers from valve.

4.  Clean gauge mounting threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal gauge parts.



CAUTION:    For temperature and pressure gauges, tape a

n 'X' on the gauge face and leave tape in-place until gauge is in service.  This will prevent injury due to broken glass or plastic if the gauge face is broken.



5.  Remove existing propane tank gauge, nozzle cover, or cap.

6.  Chase container female threads with proper size pipe tap.



CAUTION:    If pipe tap binds, stop chasing.  Do not force the tap.



7.  Clean container threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.

8.  Apply thread sealing compound to male threads, removing any excess compound with clean rag.



Ensure that compound is approved for propane service by checking container label.



9.  For Temperature gauges installed in temperature wells, fill the well with a non-corrosive liquid such as mineral oil, antifreeze or lightweight grease, prior to inserting temperature gauge.



DO NOT use water or ethylene glycol to fill temperature well.



10.  Carefully screw threaded gauge into opening.



Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten gauge more than 1/2 turn with wrench.



11.  Check the position of the gauge.  If the gauge is not properly positioned, turn clockwise until it is in the proper position.



CAUTION:    Do not turn gauge more than 1/2 turn for positioning purposes.



12.  Return gauge to services and check for leaks.

13.  Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE HYDROSTATIC RELIEF VALVE



WARNING:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor release can cause eye damage and frostbite.



        Wear splash goggles and vinyl gloves during entire operation.

        Always vent line away from you.



Remove Hydrostatic Relief Valve:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing hydrostatic relief valve, ensure that line segment is vented down to atmospheric pressure.



1.  Ensure that there are no ignition sources within 25 ft.

2.  Ensure that a fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

3.  Ensure line segment, which includes hydrostatic relief valve, is protected f

rom any energy source (i.e., block valve is closed and locked between hydrostatic relief valve and storage tank.)

4.  If there is a valve to vent the line segment, open valve and allow line to vent.

5.  If there is NO valve to vent the line segment, the line segment may be vented from a flange in the line segment as described in Step 6.

6.  Loosen the flange bolts on the opposite side of flange (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, only far enough to start the line segment venting.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If there are not other lines, the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be depressured to remove/replace the hydrostatic relief valve.



NOTE:    REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.



7.  After venting the line segment the hydrostatic relief valve may be removed by unscrewing it from the line.  A channel lock or pliers may be needed.



CAUTION:    If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 4.



Replace Hydrostatic Relief Valve:



1.  Inspect new hydrostatic relief valve for debris or defects.



NOTE:    Do not reinstall hydrostatic relief valve after removing from line.



2.  Clean valve threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts.



3.  Clean line threads with cleaning solvent approved for propane.

4.  Apply thread sealing compound to male threads.



Ensure that compound is approved for propane service by checking container label.



5.  Carefully screw threaded valve onto line.



Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.



6.  Open block valve and allow line to pressure with propane and check for leaks.

7.  Clean and store tools.



REMOVING PROPANE FROM TANKS



WARNIN

G:    Contact with liquid propane or vapor release can cause frostbite.

        Wear vinyl safety gloves during entire operation.



CAUTION:    Never leave transfer operation attended.

        If necessary to leave area, find a qualified person to attend the operation, or stop the operation.



1.  Ensure area is free of ignition sources.



If a leak or spill has occurred, allow vapor to disperse before allowing bobtail into area.



2. Ensure fire extinguisher (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.



Removing Liquid Propane:



3.  Spot bobtail/transport.

4.  Ensure bobtail/transport is chocked.

5.  Ensure that bobtail/transport is approved for propane.



Propane or liquefied petroleum gas should be clearly marked on the tank.



6.  Remove nozzle caps on bobtail/transport's liquid and vapor nozzles.



If necessary, clean connectors with a rag and replace worn or damaged O-rings.



7.  Connect liquid hose line to liquid nozzle and vapor hose line to vapor nozzle.



CAUTION:    Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.

        Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.

    

Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed away from your body.



8.  Check operation of ESVs.



WARNING:    If ESVs do not operate, STOP OPERATION and Notify Supervisor.



9.  Open valves on vapor line from bulk storage.

10.  Open valves on liquid line from bulk storage.

11.  Start pump/compressor.



WARNING:    If leak or fire occurs, close ESVs and stop pump immediately.

        Leak:  If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.

        Fire:  If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.



12.  Remove as much liquid propane as possible prior to stopping pump/compressor.

13.  Close valves on liquid and vapor lines form the bulk storage.

14.  Ensure valves on hose lines and bobtail/transport are closed.

15.  Unscrew vapor connection just enough to allow pressure to bleed off.

16.  Unscrew liquid connection just enoug

h to allow pressure to bleed off.

17.  After pressure has bled from lines, disconnect vapor and liquid hoses.

18.  Return vapor and liquid hoses to proper place at bulk storage station.

19.  Replace caps on bobtail/transport hose connections.



Flaring Residual Propane from Tanks:



1.  Ensure fire extinguishers (minimum: 18 B:C) is readily available.

2.  Ensure flaring burner located at least 25 ft. from:  Combustibles, property lines, building and storage tanks, piping and equipment.

3.  Ensure flaring burner is positioned upwind from tank being flared.

4.  Use the propane vapor transfer line to hook up the flaring burner assembly, if the line is not long enough to achieve the proper distance from the tanks, connect another LP-Gas rated vapor line to the existing line.



The flaring burner should have: orifice to restrict flow, built in shut-off, input rating of about 500,000 BTU/hr or less, and a regulator on the inlet.



5.  When assembling supply lines and burner assembly, ensure that thread sealing compound is used on all pipe threaded valves and fittings.

6.  After assembling the supply line and burner assembly, pressure test the line by leaving the burner inlet valve closed and opening and closing the supply line inlet valve.  If the line pressures up and maintains the pressure there are no leaks.



If the line fails to maintain a pressure for at least 10 minutes, check the fittings and valves for gas leaks and tighten as necessary.



7.  Ensure fire extinguishers, water hose or sprinkler is located at the base of the flaring assembly.

8.  Locate one employee at the flare assembly and one at the storage tank being flared; in case of a fire the operation can be quickly shutdown.

9.  Properly ignite the burner using the manufacturer's instruction.



CAUTION:     If an accidental fire develops during the flaring operation, immediately close all shutoff valves.



10.  Observe the pressure gauge on the service valve.  When the pressure drops below 1

5 psig, shut down the burner and allow the pressure in the tank to increase above 15 psig before restarting.

11.  When the pressure no longer increases above 15 psig, flare the remaining vapor until the burner extinguishes.

12.  Carefully loosen the supply line connections and allow line pressure to bleed down.



CAUTION:    Wear vinyl safety gloves to prevent exposure to propane vapor release when connections are loosened.



13.  Rollup supply line, clean equipment and tools and store.



We have never had any accidents or releases with off-site consequences.  However, we have an incident investigation policy:



1.  Incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release are investigated within 48 hours.

2.  A report of the investigation is prepared using the Incident Investigation form that follows.  The report is kept on file in the company office for five years.

3.  Findings and recommendations from the investigation are promptly addressed.

4.  Resolutions and corrective actions are documented on investigation form.

5.  Findings and corrective actions are reviewed with all personnel whose job tasks are affected.



We have also coordinated with the Pendleton Fire Department to respond to the unlikely event of an emergency.  Our on-site Emergency Response Policy and Procedures are described below.



EMPLOYEE TRAINING POLICY



This company complies with state and U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) rules governing training.



All persons operating ammonia/aqua processes are certified as having the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform duties and responsibilities associated with ammonia/aqua processes.  Training certifications are on record in the company office.



Refresher skills training is provided at least triennially.



Initial and refresher HAZMAT training are provided for persons involved with ammonia/aqua operations.



Employees are trained in major process changes before operating the changed p

rocess.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY





1. Emergencies are handled by onsite personnel according to the following Emergency Shutdown procedure.

2. Personnel stop leaks or extinguish fires if they can easily control the situation.

3. For more severe situations it is company policy to contact the local fire department and assist as directed by the fire department.



EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN OF AMMONIA TRANSFER



WARNING:         Anhydrous ammonia and aqua can be very harmful if inhaled.                        

        Anhydrous ammonia and aqua can cause eye, skin and respiratory tract burns.

    

Never enter vapor area without respiratory protection, protective gloves, boots, and suit.



MSDS for anhydrous ammonia and aqua are posted on site.  For First Aid/Emergency Heath Care, consult MSDS.



1.  Warn everyone at facility.

2.  If possible, shut down any operating pump or compressor by pushing remote stop button on the start/stop panel or by switching off the breaker.

3.  Notify the fire department (911).  Give your location as:     

                Pendleton Grain Growers.

                4600 McKennon Road.

4.  Evacuate persons not required for emergency action and help limit access to the area.  (Evacuate to upwind, or crosswind, location.)

5.  If entering affected area.

    A)  Put on respiratory protection

    B)  Put on gloves, suits, and boots before entering affected area.

    C)  If possible, isolate leak by closing appropriate valves.

6.  After the emergency has been resolved, and Incident Investigation for must be filled out and kept on file.



EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN FOR BULK PROPANE STORAGE TRANSFER 



WARNING:    Contact with liquid or vapor releases can cause frostbite and eye damage.

        Wear vinyl safety gloves and splash goggles.

1.  Warn everyone at the facility.



WARNING:    DO not drive bobtail or transport, they may be an ignition source. 



2.  Activate the ESVs by pressing the local or remote ESV shutdown button.

3.  If possible also shutdown the pump or compressor by pushing the

stop button on the start/stop panel or by switching off the breaker.

4.  Notify the fire department (911):  Give your location as:

                Pendleton Grain Growers

                4600 McKennon Road

5.  Evacuate persons not required for emergency action and help limit access to the area.  Evacuate to an upwind or crosswind location.

6.  DO NOT open ESVs or restart transfer process until the cause of the emergency has been resolved.

7.  After the emergency has been resolved, an Incident Investigation form must be filled out and kept on file.
